bestBHT.bht: The insults and scoffing of the people towards the Christ of God are evident, as they stood beholding the dazed multitude. The rulers, in contrast with the people, joined in the mockery with a tone of contempt. The people's insults, although not explicitly stated, reveal their true thoughts towards Jesus. The scene draws inspiration from Psalms, emphasizing the challenge for the Christ of God to save himself and prove his claim as the Messiah and chosen king.

Henry Alford: The insults of the people are by no means excluded, even if the words with them be omitted: nay they are implied."
To find a discrepancy with Matthew and Mark here, is surely unfair:—the people’s standing looking on, does not describe their mind towards Jesus.
I prefer the former: but either way, the Christ of God must be taken together.
Marvin Vincent: If he. The A. V. does not give the contemptuous emphasis on ou=tov, this fellow.
Philip Schaff: A crowd would not, however, remain still long on such an occasion, and others would be coming from the city...
But the rulers, etc. As if in contrast with the people, but the latter joined in the mockery.
The tone is that of contempt.
Archibald T. Robertson: A graphic picture of the dazed multitude" - The people stood beholding.
The language comes from Psalms 22:7" - Scoffed.
These rulers were having their day at last" - The Christ of God.
John Gill: he saved others; by healing their diseases, or raising them from the dead:
let him save himself; from death, by unnailing himself, and coming down from the cross;
if he be Christ; the Messiah, he and his followers give out he is; even the chosen of God
Christ was not chosen to be the Son of God; he was so by nature; but he was chosen to be a servant... and the Saviour of his people.
John Wesley: If thou be the Christ; Luke 23:37.
If thou be the king — The priests deride the name of Messiah: the soldiers the name of king.

bhtAttempts.bht: The insults of the people, beholding the dazed multitude, scoffed at the Christ of God. This scene, described in Luke 23:35, draws from the language of Psalms 22:7. The rulers had their day and joined in the mockery, their tone filled with contempt. The people's standing looking on does not truly describe their mind towards Jesus, as their insults are implied. The Christ of God, chosen to be a servant and the savior of his people, was now being challenged to save himself if he truly was the Son of God, the Messiah and the chosen king.

The insults of the people, scoffing at the Christ of God, are implied in their words. The dazed multitude stood beholding, as the rulers joined in the mockery with a tone filled with contempt. The Christ of God, chosen to be a servant and the savior of his people, was now challenged to save himself if he truly was the Messiah, the chosen king.
